attributes.comment:
In the United States we are given certain rights. One of those rights is the right to
choose how our families will be started. There are many of us who do not have the
privilege of giving birth to children. For those of us in this category, we are given
the opportunity to give a home to a child who does not have one. It is our right to
choose where we adopt a child from. Many of us, my husband and I included,
have chosen to give a home to children of other countries. Our decision to do this
was because we believe children in the U.S. (even those from poorer homes) have
so many more opportunities than children in other countries. Currently, a
proposed law is being considered that would make this adoption process more
costly and difficult.

Our adoption process has taken much longer than expected. There are many
families in the same situation as we are. Many countries around the world are
receiving more and more applications for adoption, therefore increasing the wait
times. If lawmakers would take the time to do some research, they would see that
the length of time for international adoptions has increased greatly over the last
two years. My husband and I began our adoption process in 2005, but because of
my husband's unemployment, our process was halted for several months. We
filed our Petition (I-600A) form in October of 2005. Our fingerprints were completed
in April of 2005. Because of the length of time we have been waiting for a referral,
we have already had to renew our fingerprints and refile our Petition. Our current
fingerprints will expire in September. Already, we have spent $1,350 in processing
fees. There is a possibility we will need to be fingerprinted a third time. We are
praying that we do not need to refile our Petition a third time.

It is concerning to me that lawmakers are considering a fee increase. And a large
increase at that. This makes things very difficult for those of us who cannot control
the long wait we are experiencing. There is nothing we can do but wait for these
countries to find the child that is meant to be with our families. The fees
associated with this process are frustrating, especially for those of us who cannot
have biological children. Adoption is the only way we can have children. And we
feel punished for choosing international adoption. But that should not be. We have
the right to choose. That is what freedom is all about. Prospective adoptive
parents everywhere are requesting that these processing fees not be increased.
We already pay enough. If the proposed increase is approved, then I ask that you
please consider extending the length of time that the biometrics and I-600A
petition are valid for. I ask that the lawmakers enlist the help of the necessary
agencies in determining an appropriate length of time to make these valid for. The
research to find out how long (on average) families are waiting on adoptions from
other countries is out there. The length of time that the I-600A and biometrics are
valid for could be based on this average time. Please do not make these decisions
without being informed of the current trends in international adoption. Thank you
for your consideration.

Sincerely,

April
A Waiting Adoptive Parent
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by April
